title: Sudbury Vertigo Risk Score
description: Identifies vertigo patients at higher risk for serious central diagnosis including stroke, TIA, vertebral artery dissection, or brain tumor in the emergency department setting.

parameters.name: motor_sensory_deficits
parameters.description: Motor or sensory deficits on examination

parameters.name: cerebellar_signs
parameters.description: Cerebellar signs/symptoms (diplopia, dysarthria, dysphagia, dysmetria, ataxia)

parameters.name: bppv_diagnosis
parameters.description: Clinical diagnosis of benign paroxysmal positional vertigo (BPPV)

ranges.interpretation: Score <5 has 100% sensitivity for ruling out serious causes of vertigo. Consider outpatient management without imaging if no other concerning features. Consider BPPV or vestibular neuritis as likely diagnoses.
Low but non-zero risk of serious cause. Consider further clinical assessment, observation, or targeted imaging based on clinical judgment and specific symptoms.
High risk for serious central cause including stroke, TIA, vertebral artery dissection, or brain tumor. Strongly consider urgent neuroimaging (CT/MRI) and neurological consultation.

references: Lelli D, Dinh J, Ahuja N, et al. Development of a Clinical Risk Score to Risk Stratify for a Serious Cause of Vertigo in Patients Presenting to the Emergency Department. Ann Emerg Med. 2024 Nov;84(5):500-511. doi: 10.1016/j.annemergmed.2024.06.003.

formula: Score = Sum of points for: Male sex + Age >65 + Hypertension + Diabetes + Motor/sensory deficits + Cerebellar signs - BPPV diagnosis. Range: -4 to 17 points.
notes: This score is designed for emergency department patients presenting with vertigo
External validation showed 100% sensitivity and 69.2% specificity for score <5
Cerebellar signs include: diplopia, dysarthria, dysphagia, dysmetria, ataxia
BPPV diagnosis is negatively associated with serious causes
Not applicable for patients with episodic vertigo lasting <24 hours
Consider vascular risk factors and clinical judgment in borderline cases
Score requires external validation before widespread clinical use
